title: Jimmy Seal
text:
James Seal (born 9 December 1950) is an English former <a href="Association%20football">footballer</a> who played as a <a href="Forward%20%28association%20football%29">striker</a>.
Career.
Born in <a href="Walton%2C%20Wakefield">Walton</a>, near <a href="Wakefield">Wakefield</a>, <a href="West%20Riding%20of%20Yorkshire">West Riding of Yorkshire</a>, Seal played for Upton Robins before he joined <a href="Wolverhampton%20Wanderers%20F.C.">Wolverhampton Wanderers</a> in March 1968. He made one appearance in the <a href="Football%20League%20First%20Division">First Division</a> for the club. During the <a href="1969%E2%80%9370%20in%20English%20football">1969–70</a> season, he was to transfer to <a href="Walsall%20F.C.">Walsall</a>. He joined <a href="Barnsley%20F.C.">Barnsley</a> in May 1971. After one season with the club, he joined <a href="York%20City%20F.C.">York City</a> in July 1972 for a fee of £6,000 and <a href="Kevin%20McMahon%20%28footballer%20born%201946%29">Kevin McMahon</a>. He had a difficult first season with the club, scoring three goals in 31 league appearances. However, during the next season, he formed a fine strike partnership with striker <a href="Chris%20Jones%20%28footballer%20born%201945%29">Chris Jones</a>, during which he scored 17 league goals, as York won promotion to the <a href="Football%20League%20Second%20Division">Second Division</a>.
Seal was <a href="York%20City%20F.C.">York City's</a> top scorer for the <a href="1974%E2%80%9375%20in%20English%20football">1974–75</a> season, with a total of 18 goals. During this season he scored a magnificent goal in a 1–1 draw against <a href="Arsenal%20F.C.">Arsenal</a> in the <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a>. He was joint top scorer with <a href="Micky%20Cave">Micky Cave</a> for the <a href="1975%E2%80%9376%20in%20English%20football">1975–76</a> season, with a total of 8 goals. He was transferred to <a href="Darlington%20F.C.">Darlington</a> in November 1976, where he played for three seasons. He finished his league career with <a href="Rochdale%20A.F.C.">Rochdale</a>.
He made his home in <a href="York">York</a> and played in local <a href="Association%20football">football</a> for a number of years, working as a self-employed painter and decorator, and later as a <a href="milkman">milkman</a>.
